ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It's Old English from the ground up--grammar, pronunciation, and all. You begin with pronunciation, move to translating prose, and then to translating poetry. There are translation homeworks for each class, a presentation during the semester, and two exams (midterm and final). It's a great class and I would recommend it highly.

An introduction to Old English that focuses on grammar for the first month and literature for the remainder of the semester.I would certainly recommend the course, but not to someone who didn't inherently like languages: part of the delight in studying Old English is learning about modern English through it.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I'm not sure yet to what extent this course will contribute to my dissertation, but it has helped deepen my understanding of Anglo-Saxon culture and literature, which has helped in my research on several latin texts from the Anglo-Saxon era.
